Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the sun rises over a quiet coral reef, 
one animal breaks the morning silence. Named for their vibrant scales 
and beak-like teeth, these parrotfish are devouring 
a particularly crunchy breakfast: rocks. It may not be immediately clear 
why any creature would take bites out of the seafloor. But the diet of these flashy foragers 
actually plays a key role in defending the coral reef’s 
complex ecosystem. Massive coral reefs 
begin with tiny coral larvae, which settle on the seafloor’s 
hard surfaces and metamorphasize into coral polyps. Over time, these polyps 
generate rock-like skeletons made of calcium carbonate. Together, colonies of polyps produce 
large three-dimensional structures, which form the basis 
of an underwater metropolis. These coral complexes are full 
of nooks and crannies that house and protect 
countless life forms. Even though coral reefs occupy less than 
one percent of the ocean floor, these dense ecosystems are home to more 
than twenty-five percent of marine life. Many fish use corals as shelters for 
sleeping and to hide from large predators between their trips foraging for seaweed. As the primary food source for many 
of the reef’s fish and invertebrates, seaweed is vital to this ecosystem. But in high densities, 
seaweed can become problematic, and even lethal to corals. Seaweed grows on the same hard open 
surfaces that coral larvae rely on, and their growth prevents new coral 
from settling and expanding. These competitors have also evolved 
a variety of ways to kill existing corals, including smothering and abrasion. Some seaweed species 
even engage in chemical warfare— synthesizing compounds 
that destroy coral on contact. This is where parrotfish come in. Like many reef fish, 
these colorful creatures eat seaweed. But unlike their neighbors, parrotfish can completely remove 
even the tiniest scraps of seaweed from the ocean floor. Their so-called beak is actually a mosaic 
of tightly-packed teeth which can scrape and grind rock, allowing them to consume every bit 
of seaweed covering a stony surface. This helps parrotfish reach seaweed 
other fish can’t consume, while simultaneously clearing out 
open space for new corals to settle and existing colonies to expand. Eating rocks is just one way parrotfish 
help manage seaweed. Through a dynamic system 
of social networks, parrotfish can convey information 
to other coral dwelling fish. Each fish’s presence and simple routine 
behaviors produce sensory information that nearby fish can see, hear, or smell. They can even detect changes in water 
pressure produced by their neighbors using a special sensory organ. All these factors can inform 
the behavior of nearby fish. For example, a fish safely entering 
an open feeding ground and not getting attacked 
means it’s safe to forage. Conversely, a fish rapidly leaving 
a location can provide an early warning that a threat is approaching. By simply trying to stay alive, these reef fish can incidentally help 
their neighbors survive— and more of these fish 
means less seaweed. Unfortunately, human activities 
over the last several decades have disrupted almost every part 
of this complex system. In many coral reefs, overfishing 
has reduced the number of parrotfish, as well as other seaweed eaters, 
such as surgeonfish and rabbitfish. This has led to unchecked seaweed growth, which threatens to degrade 
entire coral reefs. The parrotfish that remain 
live in much smaller communities. Their reduced numbers 
can weaken their social network, making surviving fish more timid 
and less effective at controlling seaweed. Today, climate change and pollution 
are lowering coral’s natural defenses while contributing to runaway 
seaweed growth— leaving reef ecosystems 
more fragile than ever. Our reefs are vitally important 
to both marine and human life. Their unparalleled biodiversity offers 
unique opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, 
and scientific research, while their rocky structures guard 
coastlines from waves and storm surges. Fortunately, continued research 
into reef species like the quirky and critical parrotfish 
can inform new strategies for preserving these essential ecosystems.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Despite the fact that coral reefs cover less than 1% of the seafloor, they account for ______ of marine life.
Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. more than 25%, D. more than 50%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary role of parrotfish in defending the coral reef ecosystem? Options: A. To build coral structures, B. To control seaweed growth, C. To protect fish from predators, D. To clean the ocean floor Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process by which coral reefs are formed. Options: A. Coral larvae settle on the seafloor and metamorphasize into coral polyps, which generate rock-like skeletons., B. Coral polyps produce large three-dimensional structures that attract other marine life., C. Seaweed grows on the seafloor, providing a habitat for coral larvae., D. Parrotfish create coral reefs by eating rocks. Correct Option: A
Question 3: A marine biologist wants to study the impact of seaweed growth on coral reefs. What would be an effective way to do this? Options: A. Introduce more parrotfish to the reef to control seaweed growth., B. Remove all seaweed from the reef to observe the effects on coral growth., C. Create an artificial reef with varying levels of seaweed growth to study the effects on coral larvae., D. Observe the behavior of parrotfish and other seaweed-eating fish on the reef. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the relationship between seaweed growth and coral reef health? Options: A. Seaweed growth is necessary for coral reefs to thrive., B. Seaweed growth can prevent new coral from settling and expanding., C. Seaweed growth has no impact on coral reef health., D. Seaweed growth is a sign of a healthy coral reef. Correct Option: B
Question 5: How do parrotfish communicate with other fish on the reef? Options: A. Through a complex system of vocalizations, B. Through a dynamic system of social networks, using sensory information, C. Through a series of complex dances, D. Through changes in water temperature Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the impact of overfishing on coral reef ecosystems? Options: A. It leads to an increase in seaweed-eating fish, which helps control seaweed growth., B. It has no impact on coral reef ecosystems., C. It reduces the number of parrotfish and other seaweed-eating fish, leading to unchecked seaweed growth., D. It leads to an increase in coral growth. Correct Option: C
Question 7: A researcher wants to study the social behavior of parrotfish on a coral reef. What would be an effective way to do this? Options: A. Observe the behavior of individual parrotfish in a laboratory setting., B. Use underwater cameras to observe the behavior of parrotfish on the reef., C. Conduct surveys of parrotfish populations on the reef., D. Create a simulated reef environment with artificial parrotfish. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the impact of climate change on coral reef ecosystems? Options: A. It leads to an increase in coral growth and a decrease in seaweed growth., B. It has no impact on coral reef ecosystems., C. It lowers coral's natural defenses and contributes to runaway seaweed growth., D. It leads to a decrease in parrotfish populations. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the importance of coral reefs to human life? Options: A. They provide a source of food for millions of people., B. They offer opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, and scientific research., C. They protect coastlines from waves and storm surges., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What can be done to preserve coral reef ecosystems? Options: A. Reduce the number of parrotfish on the reef., B. Increase the amount of seaweed on the reef., C. Continue research into reef species like parrotfish to inform new strategies for preservation., D. Build artificial reefs to replace natural ones. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, Question 4 is the most similar in terms of discussing the relationship between seaweed growth and coral reefs, which is related to the importance of coral reefs mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

But if I had to choose one that is most similar in terms of overall intent, I would say Question 9 is the closest match. Question 9 discusses the importance of coral reefs to human life, which is related to the fact mentioned in the ground truth MCQ that coral reefs cover less than 1% of the seafloor but account for a significant percentage of marine life.

However, I must emphasize that none of the generated MCQs are a direct match for the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2

**Transcript**:
As the sun rises over a quiet coral reef, 
one animal breaks the morning silence. Named for their vibrant scales 
and beak-like teeth, these parrotfish are devouring

hard surfaces and metamorphasize into coral polyps. Over time, these polyps

of nooks and crannies that house and protect 
countless life forms. Even though coral reefs occupy less than 
one percent of the ocean floor, these dense ecosystems are home to more 
than twenty-five percent of marine life. Many fish use corals as shelters for 
sleeping and to hide from large predators between their trips foraging for seaweed. As the primary food source for many

that destroy coral on contact. This is where parrotfish come in. Like many reef fish,

of tightly-packed teeth which can scrape and grind rock, allowing them to consume every bit 
of seaweed covering a stony surface. This helps parrotfish reach seaweed 
other fish can’t consume, while simultaneously clearing out 
open space for new corals to settle and existing colonies to expand. Eating rocks is just one way parrotfish 
help manage seaweed. Through a dynamic system 
of social networks, parrotfish can convey information 
to other coral dwelling fish. Each fish’s presence and simple routine 
behaviors produce sensory information that nearby fish can see, hear, or smell. They can even detect changes in water 
pressure produced by their neighbors using a special sensory organ. All these factors can inform

means it’s safe to forage. Conversely, a fish rapidly leaving 
a location can provide an early warning that a threat is approaching. By simply trying to stay alive, these reef fish can incidentally help

means less seaweed. Unfortunately, human activities 
over the last several decades have disrupted almost every part 
of this complex system. In many coral reefs, overfishing 
has reduced the number of parrotfish, as well as other seaweed eaters, 
such as surgeonfish and rabbitfish. This has led to unchecked seaweed growth, which threatens to degrade 
entire coral reefs. The parrotfish that remain 
live in much smaller communities. Their reduced numbers 
can weaken their social network, making surviving fish more timid 
and less effective at controlling seaweed. Today, climate change and pollution 
are lowering coral’s natural defenses while contributing to runaway 
seaweed growth— leaving reef ecosystems 
more fragile than ever. Our reefs are vitally important 
to both marine and human life. Their unparalleled biodiversity offers 
unique opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, 
and scientific research, while their rocky structures guard 
coastlines from waves and storm surges. Fortunately, continued research 
into reef species like the quirky and critical parrotfish 
can inform new strategies for preserving these essential ecosystems.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Parrotfish use their beak-like teeth to:
Options: A. eat other fish., B. scrape algae from the surfaces of rocks., C. defend themselves from predators., D. eat sea urchins.
Correct Option: B

Conduct surveys of parrotfish populations on the reef., D. Create a simulated reef environment with artificial parrotfish. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the impact of climate change on coral reef ecosystems? Options: A. It leads to an increase in coral growth and a decrease in seaweed growth., B. It has no impact on coral reef ecosystems., C. It lowers coral's natural defenses and contributes to runaway seaweed growth., D. It leads to a decrease in parrotfish populations. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the importance of coral reefs to human life? Options: A. They provide a source of food for millions of people., B. They offer opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, and scientific research., C. They protect coastlines from waves and storm surges., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What can be done to preserve coral reef ecosystems? Options: A. Reduce the number of parrotfish on the reef., B. Increase the amount of seaweed on the reef., C. Continue research into reef species like parrotfish to inform new strategies for preservation., D. Build artificial reefs to replace natural ones. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

A more similar question would be Question 1: What is the primary role of parrotfish in defending the coral reef ecosystem? However, this question does not specifically mention the beak-like teeth of parrotfish.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the sun rises over a quiet coral reef, 
one animal breaks the morning silence. Named for their vibrant scales 
and beak-like teeth, these parrotfish are devouring 
a particularly crunchy breakfast: rocks. It may not be immediately clear 
why any creature would take bites out of the seafloor. But the diet of these flashy foragers 
actually plays a key role in defending the coral reef’s 
complex ecosystem. Massive coral reefs 
begin with tiny coral larvae, which settle on the seafloor’s 
hard surfaces and metamorphasize into coral polyps. Over time, these polyps 
generate rock-like skeletons made of calcium carbonate. Together, colonies of polyps produce 
large three-dimensional structures, which form the basis 
of an underwater metropolis. These coral complexes are full 
of nooks and crannies that house and protect 
countless life forms. Even though coral reefs occupy less than 
one percent of the ocean floor, these dense ecosystems are home to more 
than twenty-five percent of marine life. Many fish use corals as shelters for 
sleeping and to hide from large predators between their trips foraging for seaweed. As the primary food source for many 
of the reef’s fish and invertebrates, seaweed is vital to this ecosystem. But in high densities, 
seaweed can become problematic, and even lethal to corals. Seaweed grows on the same hard open 
surfaces that coral larvae rely on, and their growth prevents new coral 
from settling and expanding. These competitors have also evolved 
a variety of ways to kill existing corals, including smothering and abrasion. Some seaweed species 
even engage in chemical warfare— synthesizing compounds 
that destroy coral on contact. This is where parrotfish come in. Like many reef fish, 
these colorful creatures eat seaweed. But unlike their neighbors, parrotfish can completely remove 
even the tiniest scraps of seaweed from the ocean floor. Their so-called beak is actually a mosaic 
of tightly-packed teeth which can scrape and grind rock, allowing them to consume every bit 
of seaweed covering a stony surface. This helps parrotfish reach seaweed 
other fish can’t consume, while simultaneously clearing out 
open space for new corals to settle and existing colonies to expand. Eating rocks is just one way parrotfish 
help manage seaweed. Through a dynamic system 
of social networks, parrotfish can convey information 
to other coral dwelling fish. Each fish’s presence and simple routine 
behaviors produce sensory information that nearby fish can see, hear, or smell. They can even detect changes in water 
pressure produced by their neighbors using a special sensory organ. All these factors can inform 
the behavior of nearby fish. For example, a fish safely entering 
an open feeding ground and not getting attacked 
means it’s safe to forage. Conversely, a fish rapidly leaving 
a location can provide an early warning that a threat is approaching. By simply trying to stay alive, these reef fish can incidentally help 
their neighbors survive— and more of these fish 
means less seaweed. Unfortunately, human activities 
over the last several decades have disrupted almost every part 
of this complex system. In many coral reefs, overfishing 
has reduced the number of parrotfish, as well as other seaweed eaters, 
such as surgeonfish and rabbitfish. This has led to unchecked seaweed growth, which threatens to degrade 
entire coral reefs. The parrotfish that remain 
live in much smaller communities. Their reduced numbers 
can weaken their social network, making surviving fish more timid 
and less effective at controlling seaweed. Today, climate change and pollution 
are lowering coral’s natural defenses while contributing to runaway 
seaweed growth— leaving reef ecosystems 
more fragile than ever. Our reefs are vitally important 
to both marine and human life. Their unparalleled biodiversity offers 
unique opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, 
and scientific research, while their rocky structures guard 
coastlines from waves and storm surges. Fortunately, continued research 
into reef species like the quirky and critical parrotfish 
can inform new strategies for preserving these essential ecosystems.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Parrotfish can communicate with one another and with other fish...
Options: A. through intentional ultrasonic clicks with their beak-like teeth., B. through intentional signals in the form of complex fin gestures., C. incidentally, by simply observing one another’s behavior., D. through parrot-like vocalizations.
Correct Option: C

Parrotfish create coral reefs by eating rocks. Correct Option: A

Create an artificial reef with varying levels of seaweed growth to study the effects on coral larvae., D. Observe the behavior of parrotfish and other seaweed-eating fish on the reef. Correct Option: C

Seaweed growth can prevent new coral from settling and expanding., C. Seaweed growth has no impact on coral reef health., D. Seaweed growth is a sign of a healthy coral reef. Correct Option: B

Conduct surveys of parrotfish populations on the reef., D. Create a simulated reef environment with artificial parrotfish. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the impact of climate change on coral reef ecosystems? Options: A. It leads to an increase in coral growth and a decrease in seaweed growth., B. It has no impact on coral reef ecosystems., C. It lowers coral's natural defenses and contributes to runaway seaweed growth., D. It leads to a decrease in parrotfish populations. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the importance of coral reefs to human life? Options: A. They provide a source of food for millions of people., B. They offer opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, and scientific research., C. They protect coastlines from waves and storm surges., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What can be done to preserve coral reef ecosystems? Options: A. Reduce the number of parrotfish on the reef., B. Increase the amount of seaweed on the reef., C. Continue research into reef species like parrotfish to inform new strategies for preservation., D. Build artificial reefs to replace natural ones. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the method of communication used by parrotfish with other fish on the reef. The correct option, "Through a dynamic system of social networks, using sensory information," is also similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "incidentally, by simply observing one another's behavior." Both options convey the idea that parrotfish communicate through subtle cues and observations rather than intentional signals.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the sun rises over a quiet coral reef, 
one animal breaks the morning silence. Named for their vibrant scales 
and beak-like teeth, these parrotfish are devouring 
a particularly crunchy breakfast: rocks. It may not be immediately clear 
why any creature would take bites out of the seafloor. But the diet of these flashy foragers 
actually plays a key role in defending the coral reef’s 
complex ecosystem. Massive coral reefs 
begin with tiny coral larvae, which settle on the seafloor’s 
hard surfaces and metamorphasize into coral polyps. Over time, these polyps 
generate rock-like skeletons made of calcium carbonate. Together, colonies of polyps produce 
large three-dimensional structures, which form the basis 
of an underwater metropolis. These coral complexes are full 
of nooks and crannies that house and protect 
countless life forms. Even though coral reefs occupy less than 
one percent of the ocean floor, these dense ecosystems are home to more 
than twenty-five percent of marine life. Many fish use corals as shelters for 
sleeping and to hide from large predators between their trips foraging for seaweed. As the primary food source for many 
of the reef’s fish and invertebrates, seaweed is vital to this ecosystem. But in high densities, 
seaweed can become problematic, and even lethal to corals. Seaweed grows on the same hard open 
surfaces that coral larvae rely on, and their growth prevents new coral 
from settling and expanding. These competitors have also evolved 
a variety of ways to kill existing corals, including smothering and abrasion. Some seaweed species 
even engage in chemical warfare— synthesizing compounds 
that destroy coral on contact. This is where parrotfish come in. Like many reef fish, 
these colorful creatures eat seaweed. But unlike their neighbors, parrotfish can completely remove 
even the tiniest scraps of seaweed from the ocean floor. Their so-called beak is actually a mosaic 
of tightly-packed teeth which can scrape and grind rock, allowing them to consume every bit 
of seaweed covering a stony surface. This helps parrotfish reach seaweed 
other fish can’t consume, while simultaneously clearing out 
open space for new corals to settle and existing colonies to expand. Eating rocks is just one way parrotfish 
help manage seaweed. Through a dynamic system 
of social networks, parrotfish can convey information 
to other coral dwelling fish. Each fish’s presence and simple routine 
behaviors produce sensory information that nearby fish can see, hear, or smell. They can even detect changes in water 
pressure produced by their neighbors using a special sensory organ. All these factors can inform 
the behavior of nearby fish. For example, a fish safely entering 
an open feeding ground and not getting attacked 
means it’s safe to forage. Conversely, a fish rapidly leaving 
a location can provide an early warning that a threat is approaching. By simply trying to stay alive, these reef fish can incidentally help 
their neighbors survive— and more of these fish 
means less seaweed. Unfortunately, human activities 
over the last several decades have disrupted almost every part 
of this complex system. In many coral reefs, overfishing 
has reduced the number of parrotfish, as well as other seaweed eaters, 
such as surgeonfish and rabbitfish. This has led to unchecked seaweed growth, which threatens to degrade 
entire coral reefs. The parrotfish that remain 
live in much smaller communities. Their reduced numbers 
can weaken their social network, making surviving fish more timid 
and less effective at controlling seaweed. Today, climate change and pollution 
are lowering coral’s natural defenses while contributing to runaway 
seaweed growth— leaving reef ecosystems 
more fragile than ever. Our reefs are vitally important 
to both marine and human life. Their unparalleled biodiversity offers 
unique opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, 
and scientific research, while their rocky structures guard 
coastlines from waves and storm surges. Fortunately, continued research 
into reef species like the quirky and critical parrotfish 
can inform new strategies for preserving these essential ecosystems.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. grow into open spaces of the reef and prevent coral settlement or growth., B. become predatory and consume fish., C. kill coral through smothering and abrasion, D. cover the seafloor and degrade entire coral reefs.
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
As the sun rises over a quiet coral reef, 
one animal breaks the morning silence. Named for their vibrant scales 
and beak-like teeth, these parrotfish are devouring 
a particularly crunchy breakfast: rocks. It may not be immediately clear 
why any creature would take bites out of the seafloor. But the diet of these flashy foragers 
actually plays a key role in defending the coral reef’s 
complex ecosystem. Massive coral reefs 
begin with tiny coral larvae, which settle on the seafloor’s 
hard surfaces and metamorphasize into coral polyps. Over time, these polyps 
generate rock-like skeletons made of calcium carbonate. Together, colonies of polyps produce 
large three-dimensional structures, which form the basis 
of an underwater metropolis. These coral complexes are full 
of nooks and crannies that house and protect 
countless life forms. Even though coral reefs occupy less than 
one percent of the ocean floor, these dense ecosystems are home to more 
than twenty-five percent of marine life. Many fish use corals as shelters for 
sleeping and to hide from large predators between their trips foraging for seaweed. As the primary food source for many 
of the reef’s fish and invertebrates, seaweed is vital to this ecosystem. But in high densities, 
seaweed can become problematic, and even lethal to corals. Seaweed grows on the same hard open 
surfaces that coral larvae rely on, and their growth prevents new coral 
from settling and expanding. These competitors have also evolved 
a variety of ways to kill existing corals, including smothering and abrasion. Some seaweed species 
even engage in chemical warfare— synthesizing compounds 
that destroy coral on contact. This is where parrotfish come in. Like many reef fish, 
these colorful creatures eat seaweed. But unlike their neighbors, parrotfish can completely remove 
even the tiniest scraps of seaweed from the ocean floor. Their so-called beak is actually a mosaic 
of tightly-packed teeth which can scrape and grind rock, allowing them to consume every bit 
of seaweed covering a stony surface. This helps parrotfish reach seaweed 
other fish can’t consume, while simultaneously clearing out 
open space for new corals to settle and existing colonies to expand. Eating rocks is just one way parrotfish 
help manage seaweed. Through a dynamic system 
of social networks, parrotfish can convey information 
to other coral dwelling fish. Each fish’s presence and simple routine 
behaviors produce sensory information that nearby fish can see, hear, or smell. They can even detect changes in water 
pressure produced by their neighbors using a special sensory organ. All these factors can inform 
the behavior of nearby fish. For example, a fish safely entering 
an open feeding ground and not getting attacked 
means it’s safe to forage. Conversely, a fish rapidly leaving 
a location can provide an early warning that a threat is approaching. By simply trying to stay alive, these reef fish can incidentally help 
their neighbors survive— and more of these fish 
means less seaweed. Unfortunately, human activities 
over the last several decades have disrupted almost every part 
of this complex system. In many coral reefs, overfishing 
has reduced the number of parrotfish, as well as other seaweed eaters, 
such as surgeonfish and rabbitfish. This has led to unchecked seaweed growth, which threatens to degrade 
entire coral reefs. The parrotfish that remain 
live in much smaller communities. Their reduced numbers 
can weaken their social network, making surviving fish more timid 
and less effective at controlling seaweed. Today, climate change and pollution 
are lowering coral’s natural defenses while contributing to runaway 
seaweed growth— leaving reef ecosystems 
more fragile than ever. Our reefs are vitally important 
to both marine and human life. Their unparalleled biodiversity offers 
unique opportunities for ecotourism, sustainable fishing, 
and scientific research, while their rocky structures guard 
coastlines from waves and storm surges. Fortunately, continued research 
into reef species like the quirky and critical parrotfish 
can inform new strategies for preserving these essential ecosystems.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2009, two researchers ran 
a simple experiment. They took everything we know 
about our solar system and calculated where every planet would be
up to 5 billion years in the future. To do so they ran over 2,000 
numerical simulations with the same exact initial conditions
except for one difference: the distance between Mercury and the Sun,
modified by less than a millimeter from one simulation to the next. Shockingly, in about 1 percent 
of their simulations, Mercury’s orbit changed so drastically 
that it could plunge into the Sun or collide with Venus. Worse yet, in one simulation it destabilized
the entire inner solar system. This was no error; 
the astonishing variety in results reveals the truth that our solar system 
may be much less stable than it seems. Astrophysicists refer to this astonishing
property of gravitational systems as the n-body problem. While we have equations 
that can completely predict the motions of two gravitating masses, our analytical tools fall short 
when faced with more populated systems. It’s actually impossible to write down
all the terms of a general formula that can exactly describe the motion
of three or more gravitating objects. Why? The issue lies in how many unknown
variables an n-body system contains. Thanks to Isaac Newton, 
we can write a set of equations to describe the gravitational force 
acting between bodies. However, when trying to find a general 
solution for the unknown variables in these equations, we’re faced with 
a mathematical constraint: for each unknown, 
there must be at least one equation that independently describes it. Initially, a two-body system appears 
to have more unknown variables for position and velocity 
than equations of motion. However, there’s a trick: consider the relative position 
and velocity of the two bodies with respect to the center 
of gravity of the system. This reduces the number of unknowns
and leaves us with a solvable system. With three or more orbiting objects 
in the picture, everything gets messier. Even with the same mathematical trick 
of considering relative motions, we’re left with more unknowns 
than equations describing them. There are simply too many variables
for this system of equations to be untangled into a general solution. But what does it actually look like 
for objects in our universe to move according to analytically 
unsolvable equations of motion? A system of three stars—
like Alpha Centauri— could come crashing
into one another or, more likely, some might get flung out of orbit 
after a long time of apparent stability. Other than a few highly improbable 
stable configurations, almost every possible case 
is unpredictable on long timescales. Each has an astronomically large range
of potential outcomes, dependent on the tiniest of differences
in position and velocity. This behaviour is known 
as chaotic by physicists, and is an important characteristic 
of n-body systems. Such a system is still deterministic—
meaning there’s nothing random about it. If multiple systems start 
from the exact same conditions, they’ll always reach the same result. But give one a little shove at the start,
and all bets are off. That’s clearly relevant 
for human space missions, when complicated orbits need 
to be calculated with great precision. Thankfully, continuous advancements
in computer simulations offer a number of ways
to avoid catastrophe. By approximating the solutions 
with increasingly powerful processors, we can more confidently predict the motion
of n-body systems on long time-scales. And if one body in a group 
of three is so light it exerts no significant force 
on the other two, the system behaves, with very good 
approximation, as a two-body system. This approach is known 
as the “restricted three-body problem.” It proves extremely useful 
in describing, for example, an asteroid in the Earth-Sun 
gravitational field, or a small planet in the field 
of a black hole and a star. As for our solar system, 
you’ll be happy to hear that we can have reasonable confidence
in its stability for at least the next 
several hundred million years. Though if another star, launched from across the galaxy, 
is on its way to us, all bets are off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The statement “The Solar System will become unstable within the next 100 million years” reflects:
Options: A. An absolute truth., B. A possibility., C. A falsity., D. A sincere hope.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In 2009, what experiment did two researchers run to understand the stability of our solar system? Options: A. They calculated the orbits of planets up to 1 billion years in the future., B. They ran over 2,000 numerical simulations with varying distances between Mercury and the Sun., C. They observed the motion of asteroids in the Earth-Sun gravitational field., D. They studied the orbits of three stars in the Alpha Centauri system. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term used to describe the property of gravitational systems that makes it difficult to predict the motion of three or more objects? Options: A. The n-body problem, B. The restricted three-body problem, C. Gravitational instability, D. Chaotic motion Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with solving the n-body problem? Options: A. There are too many equations to solve., B. There are too many unknown variables and not enough equations to describe them., C. The equations are too complex to solve analytically., D. The problem is too computationally intensive. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the "trick" used to reduce the number of unknown variables in a two-body system? Options: A. Considering the relative position and velocity of the two bodies with respect to the center of gravity., B. Ignoring the gravitational force between the two bodies., C. Assuming the two bodies are identical., D. Using numerical simulations to approximate the solution. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the likely outcome for a system of three stars, like Alpha Centauri, over a long period of time? Options: A. They will maintain a stable orbit., B. They will collide with each other., C. Some stars might get flung out of orbit after a long time of apparent stability., D. They will merge into a single star. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the behavior of n-body systems that are highly sensitive to initial conditions? Options: A. Chaotic, B. Deterministic, C. Random, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why is the restricted three-body problem useful in describing certain astronomical systems? Options: A. It allows for exact analytical solutions., B. It provides a good approximation for systems where one body is much lighter than the others., C. It is computationally less intensive than the full n-body problem., D. It is more accurate than numerical simulations. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the implication of the n-body problem for human space missions? Options: A. It makes it impossible to calculate orbits with precision., B. It requires the use of numerical simulations to approximate solutions., C. It means that small errors in initial conditions can lead to catastrophic outcomes., D. It has no significant impact on space missions. Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can advancements in computer simulations help with predicting the motion of n-body systems? Options: A. By providing exact analytical solutions., B. By approximating solutions with increasingly powerful processors., C. By reducing the number of unknown variables., D. By ignoring the gravitational force between bodies. Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the timeframe for which we can have reasonable confidence in the stability of our solar system? Options: A. The next few thousand years., B. The next few million years., C. The next several hundred million years., D. The next few billion years. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2009, two researchers ran 
a simple experiment. They took everything we know 
about our solar system and calculated where every planet would be
up to 5 billion years in the future. To do so they ran over 2,000 
numerical simulations with the same exact initial conditions
except for one difference: the distance between Mercury and the Sun,
modified by less than a millimeter from one simulation to the next. Shockingly, in about 1 percent 
of their simulations, Mercury’s orbit changed so drastically 
that it could plunge into the Sun or collide with Venus. Worse yet, in one simulation it destabilized
the entire inner solar system. This was no error; 
the astonishing variety in results reveals the truth that our solar system 
may be much less stable than it seems. Astrophysicists refer to this astonishing
property of gravitational systems as the n-body problem. While we have equations 
that can completely predict the motions of two gravitating masses, our analytical tools fall short 
when faced with more populated systems. It’s actually impossible to write down
all the terms of a general formula that can exactly describe the motion
of three or more gravitating objects. Why? The issue lies in how many unknown
variables an n-body system contains. Thanks to Isaac Newton, 
we can write a set of equations to describe the gravitational force 
acting between bodies. However, when trying to find a general 
solution for the unknown variables in these equations, we’re faced with 
a mathematical constraint: for each unknown, 
there must be at least one equation that independently describes it. Initially, a two-body system appears 
to have more unknown variables for position and velocity 
than equations of motion. However, there’s a trick: consider the relative position 
and velocity of the two bodies with respect to the center 
of gravity of the system. This reduces the number of unknowns
and leaves us with a solvable system. With three or more orbiting objects 
in the picture, everything gets messier. Even with the same mathematical trick 
of considering relative motions, we’re left with more unknowns 
than equations describing them. There are simply too many variables
for this system of equations to be untangled into a general solution. But what does it actually look like 
for objects in our universe to move according to analytically 
unsolvable equations of motion? A system of three stars—
like Alpha Centauri— could come crashing
into one another or, more likely, some might get flung out of orbit 
after a long time of apparent stability. Other than a few highly improbable 
stable configurations, almost every possible case 
is unpredictable on long timescales. Each has an astronomically large range
of potential outcomes, dependent on the tiniest of differences
in position and velocity. This behaviour is known 
as chaotic by physicists, and is an important characteristic 
of n-body systems. Such a system is still deterministic—
meaning there’s nothing random about it. If multiple systems start 
from the exact same conditions, they’ll always reach the same result. But give one a little shove at the start,
and all bets are off. That’s clearly relevant 
for human space missions, when complicated orbits need 
to be calculated with great precision. Thankfully, continuous advancements
in computer simulations offer a number of ways
to avoid catastrophe. By approximating the solutions 
with increasingly powerful processors, we can more confidently predict the motion
of n-body systems on long time-scales. And if one body in a group 
of three is so light it exerts no significant force 
on the other two, the system behaves, with very good 
approximation, as a two-body system. This approach is known 
as the “restricted three-body problem.” It proves extremely useful 
in describing, for example, an asteroid in the Earth-Sun 
gravitational field, or a small planet in the field 
of a black hole and a star. As for our solar system, 
you’ll be happy to hear that we can have reasonable confidence
in its stability for at least the next 
several hundred million years. Though if another star, launched from across the galaxy, 
is on its way to us, all bets are off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In simple terms, why the three-body problem cannot be solved analytically?
Options: A. Newton’s law of gravitation can be applied only to two bodies at a time., B. Computers currently available are not powerful enough., C. Wait, what? Of course it can be solved analytically!, D. There are too many unknowns.
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In 2009, what experiment did two researchers run to understand the stability of our solar system? Options: A. They calculated the orbits of planets up to 1 billion years in the future., B. They ran over 2,000 numerical simulations with varying distances between Mercury and the Sun., C. They observed the motion of asteroids in the Earth-Sun gravitational field., D. They studied the orbits of three stars in the Alpha Centauri system. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term used to describe the property of gravitational systems that makes it difficult to predict the motion of three or more objects? Options: A. The n-body problem, B. The restricted three-body problem, C. Gravitational instability, D. Chaotic motion Correct Option: A

There are too many unknown variables and not enough equations to describe them., C. The equations are too complex to solve analytically., D. The problem is too computationally intensive. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the "trick" used to reduce the number of unknown variables in a two-body system? Options: A. Considering the relative position and velocity of the two bodies with respect to the center of gravity., B. Ignoring the gravitational force between the two bodies., C. Assuming the two bodies are identical., D. Using numerical simulations to approximate the solution. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the likely outcome for a system of three stars, like Alpha Centauri, over a long period of time? Options: A. They will maintain a stable orbit., B. They will collide with each other., C. Some stars might get flung out of orbit after a long time of apparent stability., D. They will merge into a single star. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the behavior of n-body systems that are highly sensitive to initial conditions? Options: A. Chaotic, B. Deterministic, C. Random, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why is the restricted three-body problem useful in describing certain astronomical systems? Options: A. It allows for exact analytical solutions., B. It provides a good approximation for systems where one body is much lighter than the others., C. It is computationally less intensive than the full n-body problem., D. It is more accurate than numerical simulations. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the implication of the n-body problem for human space missions? Options: A. It makes it impossible to calculate orbits with precision., B. It requires the use of numerical simulations to approximate solutions., C. It means that small errors in initial conditions can lead to catastrophic outcomes., D. It has no significant impact on space missions. Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can advancements in computer simulations help with predicting the motion of n-body systems? Options: A. By providing exact analytical solutions., B. By approximating solutions with increasingly powerful processors., C. By reducing the number of unknown variables., D. By ignoring the gravitational force between bodies. Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the timeframe for which we can have reasonable confidence in the stability of our solar system? Options: A. The next few thousand years., B. The next few million years., C. The next several hundred million years., D. The next few billion years. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions address the main issue with solving the n-body problem, which is the presence of too many unknown variables and not enough equations to describe them. The correct option in both questions (D in the ground truth MCQ and B in Question 3) highlights this specific challenge.

**Transcript**:
In 2009, two researchers ran 
a simple experiment. They took everything we know 
about our solar system and calculated where every planet would be
up to 5 billion years in the future. To do so they ran over 2,000 
numerical simulations with the same exact initial conditions
except for one difference: the distance between Mercury and the Sun,
modified by less than a millimeter from one simulation to the next. Shockingly, in about 1 percent 
of their simulations, Mercury’s orbit changed so drastically 
that it could plunge into the Sun or collide with Venus. Worse yet, in one simulation it destabilized
the entire inner solar system. This was no error; 
the astonishing variety in results reveals the truth that our solar system 
may be much less stable than it seems. Astrophysicists refer to this astonishing
property of gravitational systems as the n-body problem. While we have equations 
that can completely predict the motions of two gravitating masses, our analytical tools fall short 
when faced with more populated systems. It’s actually impossible to write down
all the terms of a general formula that can exactly describe the motion
of three or more gravitating objects. Why? The issue lies in how many unknown
variables an n-body system contains. Thanks to Isaac Newton, 
we can write a set of equations to describe the gravitational force 
acting between bodies. However, when trying to find a general 
solution for the unknown variables in these equations, we’re faced with 
a mathematical constraint: for each unknown, 
there must be at least one equation that independently describes it. Initially, a two-body system appears 
to have more unknown variables for position and velocity 
than equations of motion. However, there’s a trick: consider the relative position 
and velocity of the two bodies with respect to the center 
of gravity of the system. This reduces the number of unknowns
and leaves us with a solvable system. With three or more orbiting objects 
in the picture, everything gets messier. Even with the same mathematical trick 
of considering relative motions, we’re left with more unknowns 
than equations describing them. There are simply too many variables
for this system of equations to be untangled into a general solution. But what does it actually look like 
for objects in our universe to move according to analytically

like Alpha Centauri— could come crashing
into one another or, more likely, some might get flung out of orbit 
after a long time of apparent stability. Other than a few highly improbable 
stable configurations, almost every possible case 
is unpredictable on long timescales. Each has an astronomically large range
of potential outcomes, dependent on the tiniest of differences
in position and velocity. This behaviour is known 
as chaotic by physicists, and is an important characteristic 
of n-body systems. Such a system is still deterministic—
meaning there’s nothing random about it. If multiple systems start

you’ll be happy to hear that we can have reasonable confidence
in its stability for at least the next 
several hundred million years. Though if another star, launched from across the galaxy, 
is on its way to us, all bets are off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. A change in the initial conditions can lead to significantly different time evolutions., B. Its time evolution is completely random, unpredictable., C. Starting from the exact same initial conditions, the time evolution is every time different., D. The usual state of my room.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In 2009, two researchers ran 
a simple experiment. They took everything we know 
about our solar system and calculated where every planet would be
up to 5 billion years in the future. To do so they ran over 2,000 
numerical simulations with the same exact initial conditions
except for one difference: the distance between Mercury and the Sun,
modified by less than a millimeter from one simulation to the next. Shockingly, in about 1 percent 
of their simulations, Mercury’s orbit changed so drastically 
that it could plunge into the Sun or collide with Venus. Worse yet, in one simulation it destabilized
the entire inner solar system. This was no error; 
the astonishing variety in results reveals the truth that our solar system 
may be much less stable than it seems. Astrophysicists refer to this astonishing
property of gravitational systems as the n-body problem. While we have equations 
that can completely predict the motions of two gravitating masses, our analytical tools fall short 
when faced with more populated systems. It’s actually impossible to write down
all the terms of a general formula that can exactly describe the motion
of three or more gravitating objects. Why? The issue lies in how many unknown
variables an n-body system contains. Thanks to Isaac Newton, 
we can write a set of equations to describe the gravitational force 
acting between bodies. However, when trying to find a general 
solution for the unknown variables in these equations, we’re faced with 
a mathematical constraint: for each unknown, 
there must be at least one equation that independently describes it. Initially, a two-body system appears 
to have more unknown variables for position and velocity 
than equations of motion. However, there’s a trick: consider the relative position 
and velocity of the two bodies with respect to the center 
of gravity of the system. This reduces the number of unknowns
and leaves us with a solvable system. With three or more orbiting objects 
in the picture, everything gets messier. Even with the same mathematical trick 
of considering relative motions, we’re left with more unknowns 
than equations describing them. There are simply too many variables
for this system of equations to be untangled into a general solution. But what does it actually look like 
for objects in our universe to move according to analytically 
unsolvable equations of motion? A system of three stars—
like Alpha Centauri— could come crashing
into one another or, more likely, some might get flung out of orbit 
after a long time of apparent stability. Other than a few highly improbable 
stable configurations, almost every possible case 
is unpredictable on long timescales. Each has an astronomically large range
of potential outcomes, dependent on the tiniest of differences
in position and velocity. This behaviour is known 
as chaotic by physicists, and is an important characteristic 
of n-body systems. Such a system is still deterministic—
meaning there’s nothing random about it. If multiple systems start 
from the exact same conditions, they’ll always reach the same result. But give one a little shove at the start,
and all bets are off. That’s clearly relevant 
for human space missions, when complicated orbits need 
to be calculated with great precision. Thankfully, continuous advancements
in computer simulations offer a number of ways
to avoid catastrophe. By approximating the solutions 
with increasingly powerful processors, we can more confidently predict the motion
of n-body systems on long time-scales. And if one body in a group 
of three is so light it exerts no significant force 
on the other two, the system behaves, with very good 
approximation, as a two-body system. This approach is known 
as the “restricted three-body problem.” It proves extremely useful 
in describing, for example, an asteroid in the Earth-Sun 
gravitational field, or a small planet in the field 
of a black hole and a star. As for our solar system, 
you’ll be happy to hear that we can have reasonable confidence
in its stability for at least the next 
several hundred million years. Though if another star, launched from across the galaxy, 
is on its way to us, all bets are off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: An excellent approximation to the real solution of the three-body problem can generally be found ____
Options: A. numerically, by approximating the equations with a computer., B. only if the three bodies have negligible mass., C. under no circumstances., D. analytically, just as in the case of a two-body problem.
Correct Option: A

after a long time of apparent stability. Other than a few highly improbable 
stable configurations, almost every possible case 
is unpredictable on long timescales. Each has an astronomically large range
of potential outcomes, dependent on the tiniest of differences
in position and velocity. This behaviour is known 
as chaotic by physicists, and is an important characteristic 
of n-body systems. Such a system is still deterministic—
meaning there’s nothing random about it. If multiple systems start 
from the exact same conditions, they’ll always reach the same result. But give one a little shove at the start,
and all bets are off. That’s clearly relevant 
for human space missions, when complicated orbits need 
to be calculated with great precision. Thankfully, continuous advancements
in computer simulations offer a number of ways
to avoid catastrophe. By approximating the solutions 
with increasingly powerful processors, we can more confidently predict the motion
of n-body systems on long time-scales. And if one body in a group 
of three is so light it exerts no significant force 
on the other two, the system behaves, with very good 
approximation, as a two-body system. This approach is known 
as the “restricted three-body problem.” It proves extremely useful 
in describing, for example, an asteroid in the Earth-Sun 
gravitational field, or a small planet in the field 
of a black hole and a star. As for our solar system, 
you’ll be happy to hear that we can have reasonable confidence
in its stability for at least the next 
several hundred million years. Though if another star, launched from across the galaxy, 
is on its way to us, all bets are off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following systems can be reasonably described with a restricted three-body approach?
Options: A. A system composed by three stars of similar mass., B. A system composed by two similar asteroids and the planet Earth., C. A system composed by a star, a planet and a small asteroid., D. A system composed by three tele-communication satellites.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In 2009, what experiment did two researchers run to understand the stability of our solar system? Options: A. They calculated the orbits of planets up to 1 billion years in the future., B. They ran over 2,000 numerical simulations with varying distances between Mercury and the Sun., C. They observed the motion of asteroids in the Earth-Sun gravitational field., D. They studied the orbits of three stars in the Alpha Centauri system. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term used to describe the property of gravitational systems that makes it difficult to predict the motion of three or more objects? Options: A. The n-body problem, B. The restricted three-body problem, C. Gravitational instability, D. Chaotic motion Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the main issue with solving the n-body problem? Options: A. There are too many equations to solve., B. There are too many unknown variables and not enough equations to describe them., C. The equations are too complex to solve analytically., D. The problem is too computationally intensive. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the "trick" used to reduce the number of unknown variables in a two-body system? Options: A. Considering the relative position and velocity of the two bodies with respect to the center of gravity., B. Ignoring the gravitational force between the two bodies., C. Assuming the two bodies are identical., D. Using numerical simulations to approximate the solution. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the likely outcome for a system of three stars, like Alpha Centauri, over a long period of time? Options: A. They will maintain a stable orbit., B. They will collide with each other., C. Some stars might get flung out of orbit after a long time of apparent stability., D. They will merge into a single star. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the behavior of n-body systems that are highly sensitive to initial conditions? Options: A. Chaotic, B. Deterministic, C. Random, D. Unpredictable Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why is the restricted three-body problem useful in describing certain astronomical systems? Options: A. It allows for exact analytical solutions., B. It provides a good approximation for systems where one body is much lighter than the others., C. It is computationally less intensive than the full n-body problem., D. It is more accurate than numerical simulations. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the implication of the n-body problem for human space missions? Options: A. It makes it impossible to calculate orbits with precision., B. It requires the use of numerical simulations to approximate solutions., C. It means that small errors in initial conditions can lead to catastrophic outcomes., D. It has no significant impact on space missions. Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can advancements in computer simulations help with predicting the motion of n-body systems? Options: A. By providing exact analytical solutions., B. By approximating solutions with increasingly powerful processors., C. By reducing the number of unknown variables., D. By ignoring the gravitational force between bodies. Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the timeframe for which we can have reasonable confidence in the stability of our solar system? Options: A. The next few thousand years., B. The next few million years., C. The next several hundred million years., D. The next few billion years. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the restricted three-body problem and its application to certain astronomical systems. The options for Question 7 also align with the ground truth MCQ, with option B describing a scenario where one body is much lighter than the others, which is similar to the correct option C in the ground truth MCQ. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’re a biologist on a mission to keep the rare honeybee 
Apis Trifecta from going extinct. The last 60 bees of the species 
are in your terrarium. You’ve already constructed wire frames
of the appropriate size and shape. Now you need to turn 
them into working beehives by helping the bees fill 
every hex with wax. There are two ways to fill a given hex. The first is to place a bee into it. Once placed, a bee cannot 
be removed without killing it. The second: if at any point an unfilled hex has three
or more neighboring wax-filled hexes, the bees already in the hive 
will move in and transform it. Once the bees have transformed 
every hex in a hive, you can place an additional bee inside
and it’ll specialize into a queen. The hive, if well cared for, 
will eventually produce new bees and continue the species. If there are no hexes with three or more 
transformed neighbors, the bees will just sit and wait. And once a bee transforms a hex, 
it can never become a queen. You could put 59 bees in one wire hive,
wait till they transform all the hexes, and then create a queen. But then just one collapse 
would end the species. The more viable hives 
you can make now, the better. So how many can you make with 60 bees? Pause the video to figure
it out yourself Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Answer in 0 What you're looking for here is some 
kind of self-sustaining chain reaction, where a small number of bees 
will transform an entire hive. The lower the number of bees needed,
the better. So how low can we go, 
and how can we engineer a chain reaction? Let’s start with the first question. There's a really clever approach to this, which involves counting the sides 
of the filled-in hexes, and examining their total perimeter. Let’s suppose we put bees 
in these three hexes. The total transformed 
perimeter has 18 sides. But the middle hex 
has three transformed neighbors, so the bees will transform it too. What happens to the perimeter? It’s still 18! And even after the bees transform the next
sets of hexes with three neighbors, it still won’t change. What’s going on here? Each hex that has at least three sides 
touching the bee-friendly space will remove those sides from the perimeter
when it transforms. Then it adds at most three new sides 
to the perimeter. So the perimeter of the transformed hexes
will either stay the same or shrink. The final perimeter 
of the entire hive is 54, so the total perimeter of the hexes 
we place bees in at the start must be at least 54 as well. Dividing that 54 by the six sides 
on each non-adjacent hex tells us it’ll take at least 9 bees 
to transform the entire hive. That’s a great start, but we still have the tough question 
of where the nine bees should go, and if we’ll need more. Let’s think smaller. We already know that three bees could
completely transform a hive this big. What about a slightly bigger one? The perimeter of this hive is 30, which means we’ll need 
at least 5 bees to fill it in. With 6 it’d be easy. Placing them like this would fill out 
the whole hive in just three steps. But we can do better! We don’t actually need to place 
a bee on this hex, since the other bees will transform
that spot on their own. It looks like we have 
the beginning of a pattern. Can we extend it to our full hive? That would mean placing 
our 9 bees like so. Once they get to work, 
they’ll create a chain reaction that fills in the center of the hive 
and extend it to its edges. Add a 10th bee to the completed hive 
and it becomes a queen. Repeat that process five more times and you’ve helped the last 60 members
of Apis trifecta create 6 producing hives. All in all, 
it’s a pretty good bee-ginning.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many bees do you have in your terrarium?
Options: A. 50, B. 60, C. 70, D. 100
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary goal of the biologist in the given scenario? Options: A. To study the behavior of Apis Trifecta bees, B. To create a new species of bees, C. To prevent the extinction of Apis Trifecta bees, D. To develop a new method for beekeeping Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the condition for bees to transform an unfilled hex into a wax-filled hex? Options: A. The hex must have at least one neighboring wax-filled hex, B. The hex must have at least two neighboring wax-filled hexes, C. The hex must have at least three neighboring wax-filled hexes, D. The hex must have at least four neighboring wax-filled hexes Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens to the perimeter of the transformed hexes as the bees continue to transform new hexes? Options: A. The perimeter increases, B. The perimeter decreases, C. The perimeter remains the same or decreases, D. The perimeter becomes irregular Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the minimum number of bees required to transform the entire hive, based on the perimeter calculation? Options: A. 5 bees, B. 6 bees, C. 9 bees, D. 10 bees Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the purpose of placing the 10th bee in the completed hive? Options: A. To help transform the remaining hexes, B. To create a new queen bee, C. To increase the hive's population, D. To improve the hive's structure Correct Option: B
Question 6: If you were to place 59 bees in one wire hive, what would be the potential risk? Options: A. The hive would become too crowded, B. The bees would not have enough food, C. A single collapse would end the species, D. The hive would not produce new bees Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the benefit of creating multiple hives with fewer bees each? Options: A. It increases the overall population of bees, B. It reduces the risk of extinction, C. It improves the quality of the honey produced, D. It simplifies the process of caring for the bees Correct Option: B
Question 8: How many producing hives can be created with the last 60 members of Apis Trifecta? Options: A. 3 hives, B. 4 hives, C. 5 hives, D. 6 hives Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the key insight that allows the biologist to engineer a chain reaction in the hive? Options: A. The importance of the queen bee, B. The role of the perimeter in determining the number of bees needed, C. The need for a specific pattern of bee placement, D. The impact of the hive's size on the number of bees required Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of the biologist's efforts in this scenario? Options: A. To create a new species of bees, B. To develop a more efficient method for beekeeping, C. To ensure the survival of Apis Trifecta, D. To improve the quality of honey produced Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall context and intent, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is not present in the list, but if I had to choose one that is somewhat related, I would choose:

 Question 8: How many producing hives can be created with the last 60 members of Apis Trifecta? Options: A. 3 hives, B. 4 hives, C. 5 hives, D. 6 hives Correct Option: D

However, this question does not match the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable generated MCQ would be:

Question: How many bees are in your terrarium? Options: A. 50, B. 60, C. 70, D. 100 Correct Option: B

Since this question is not present in the list, I would say that there is no matching generated MCQ.

to the perimeter. So the perimeter of the transformed hexes
will either stay the same or shrink. The final perimeter 
of the entire hive is 54, so the total perimeter of the hexes 
we place bees in at the start must be at least 54 as well. Dividing that 54 by the six sides 
on each non-adjacent hex tells us it’ll take at least 9 bees 
to transform the entire hive. That’s a great start, but we still have the tough question 
of where the nine bees should go, and if we’ll need more. Let’s think smaller. We already know that three bees could
completely transform a hive this big. What about a slightly bigger one? The perimeter of this hive is 30, which means we’ll need 
at least 5 bees to fill it in. With 6 it’d be easy. Placing them like this would fill out 
the whole hive in just three steps. But we can do better! We don’t actually need to place 
a bee on this hex, since the other bees will transform
that spot on their own. It looks like we have 
the beginning of a pattern. Can we extend it to our full hive? That would mean placing 
our 9 bees like so. Once they get to work, 
they’ll create a chain reaction that fills in the center of the hive 
and extend it to its edges. Add a 10th bee to the completed hive 
and it becomes a queen. Repeat that process five more times and you’ve helped the last 60 members
of Apis trifecta create 6 producing hives. All in all, 
it’s a pretty good bee-ginning.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What other property of the hives ends up being helpful to examine?
Options: A. Perimeter, B. Area, C. Volume, D. Honey production
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary goal of the biologist in the given scenario? Options: A. To study the behavior of Apis Trifecta bees, B. To create a new species of bees, C. To prevent the extinction of Apis Trifecta bees, D. To develop a new method for beekeeping Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the condition for bees to transform an unfilled hex into a wax-filled hex? Options: A. The hex must have at least one neighboring wax-filled hex, B. The hex must have at least two neighboring wax-filled hexes, C. The hex must have at least three neighboring wax-filled hexes, D. The hex must have at least four neighboring wax-filled hexes Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens to the perimeter of the transformed hexes as the bees continue to transform new hexes? Options: A. The perimeter increases, B. The perimeter decreases, C. The perimeter remains the same or decreases, D. The perimeter becomes irregular Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the minimum number of bees required to transform the entire hive, based on the perimeter calculation? Options: A. 5 bees, B. 6 bees, C. 9 bees, D. 10 bees Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the purpose of placing the 10th bee in the completed hive? Options: A. To help transform the remaining hexes, B. To create a new queen bee, C. To increase the hive's population, D. To improve the hive's structure Correct Option: B
Question 6: If you were to place 59 bees in one wire hive, what would be the potential risk? Options: A. The hive would become too crowded, B. The bees would not have enough food, C. A single collapse would end the species, D. The hive would not produce new bees Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the benefit of creating multiple hives with fewer bees each? Options: A. It increases the overall population of bees, B. It reduces the risk of extinction, C. It improves the quality of the honey produced, D. It simplifies the process of caring for the bees Correct Option: B
Question 8: How many producing hives can be created with the last 60 members of Apis Trifecta? Options: A. 3 hives, B. 4 hives, C. 5 hives, D. 6 hives Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the key insight that allows the biologist to engineer a chain reaction in the hive? Options: A. The importance of the queen bee, B. The role of the perimeter in determining the number of bees needed, C. The need for a specific pattern of bee placement, D. The impact of the hive's size on the number of bees required Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of the biologist's efforts in this scenario? Options: A. To create a new species of bees, B. To develop a more efficient method for beekeeping, C. To ensure the survival of Apis Trifecta, D. To improve the quality of honey produced Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’re a biologist on a mission to keep the rare honeybee 
Apis Trifecta from going extinct. The last 60 bees of the species 
are in your terrarium. You’ve already constructed wire frames
of the appropriate size and shape. Now you need to turn 
them into working beehives by helping the bees fill 
every hex with wax. There are two ways to fill a given hex. The first is to place a bee into it. Once placed, a bee cannot 
be removed without killing it. The second: if at any point an unfilled hex has three
or more neighboring wax-filled hexes, the bees already in the hive 
will move in and transform it. Once the bees have transformed 
every hex in a hive, you can place an additional bee inside
and it’ll specialize into a queen. The hive, if well cared for, 
will eventually produce new bees and continue the species. If there are no hexes with three or more 
transformed neighbors, the bees will just sit and wait. And once a bee transforms a hex, 
it can never become a queen. You could put 59 bees in one wire hive,
wait till they transform all the hexes, and then create a queen. But then just one collapse 
would end the species. The more viable hives 
you can make now, the better. So how many can you make with 60 bees? Pause the video to figure
it out yourself Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Answer in 0 What you're looking for here is some 
kind of self-sustaining chain reaction, where a small number of bees 
will transform an entire hive. The lower the number of bees needed,
the better. So how low can we go, 
and how can we engineer a chain reaction? Let’s start with the first question. There's a really clever approach to this, which involves counting the sides 
of the filled-in hexes, and examining their total perimeter. Let’s suppose we put bees 
in these three hexes. The total transformed 
perimeter has 18 sides. But the middle hex 
has three transformed neighbors, so the bees will transform it too. What happens to the perimeter? It’s still 18! And even after the bees transform the next
sets of hexes with three neighbors, it still won’t change. What’s going on here? Each hex that has at least three sides 
touching the bee-friendly space will remove those sides from the perimeter
when it transforms. Then it adds at most three new sides 
to the perimeter. So the perimeter of the transformed hexes
will either stay the same or shrink. The final perimeter 
of the entire hive is 54, so the total perimeter of the hexes 
we place bees in at the start must be at least 54 as well. Dividing that 54 by the six sides 
on each non-adjacent hex tells us it’ll take at least 9 bees 
to transform the entire hive. That’s a great start, but we still have the tough question 
of where the nine bees should go, and if we’ll need more. Let’s think smaller. We already know that three bees could
completely transform a hive this big. What about a slightly bigger one? The perimeter of this hive is 30, which means we’ll need 
at least 5 bees to fill it in. With 6 it’d be easy. Placing them like this would fill out 
the whole hive in just three steps. But we can do better! We don’t actually need to place 
a bee on this hex, since the other bees will transform
that spot on their own. It looks like we have 
the beginning of a pattern. Can we extend it to our full hive? That would mean placing 
our 9 bees like so. Once they get to work, 
they’ll create a chain reaction that fills in the center of the hive 
and extend it to its edges. Add a 10th bee to the completed hive 
and it becomes a queen. Repeat that process five more times and you’ve helped the last 60 members
of Apis trifecta create 6 producing hives. All in all, 
it’s a pretty good bee-ginning.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If a single bee is placed into a hive, how many hexes will it transform on its own?
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4
Correct Option: A
